post.date: Posted: Sat Apr 08, 2006 11:51 pm Post subject: miscellaneous rig questions
post.author: Zergxes
post.body:
I have a few random questions about D3/Q4 rigs.

1.) what is the optimal number (or maybe just a good target number) of bones to keep things efficent for NPC monsters and for multiplayer characters?

2.) There are some 'floating' bones on some of the Q4 monster rigs that seem to translate around, particularly on the chest of the beserker. How are those set up?

3.) The rigs in Q4 use an inverted foot rig, should I stick to that or can I do the heel-less rig to save bones?

-Right now I'm just slamming out art for my portfolio but I would like to not back myself into a corner should I get the opportunity to get these in game.

Thanks in advance.

post.date: Posted: Wed Jan 26, 2005 9:16 pm Post subject: Animators Think Tank.
post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:

  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor

Tentative Members:

  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line

On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:

  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).

  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.

  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.

  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.

  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

_________________
Hexen Edge Of Chaos
Ultimate Mod

Personal websites:
http://www.fabianband.com
http://pixels.ontheweb.nl

Last edited by BloodRayne on Sat Jan 29, 2005 9:22 am; edited 3 times in total

post.date: Posted: Thu Jan 27, 2005 5:25 am Post subject: Re: Should be sticky: Animators Think Tank.
post.author: Dingo_aus
post.body:
BloodRayne wrote:


1 - The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.

2 - Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.


Maybe the best way to get the best "bang-for-buck" is to make it a condition that mod makers can only ask the ATT for a tutorial to be written for an specific area (but not for a specific mod or specific model). That way general information any mod maker can use is produced.

post.date: Posted: Sun Jan 30, 2005 1:46 am Post subject:
post.author: fault_line
post.body:
Ahh.. i see well i guess whatever works the least painfully for you. Im not sure which 3D package you use, but it may possible you can setup key bone poses and copy paste within the software.

Something like this for lightwave : http://www.thomas4d.com/html/t4d_rigging_tools.html (halfway down page - Negative Frame paste plugins)
The bone phoneme positions in the face are created in negative frames then using the plugin they're essentially pasted into the frame you choose.

post.date: Posted: Fri Feb 11, 2005 7:09 pm Post subject:
post.author: crimity
post.body:
Like Bloodrayne said.. the animators think tank is not a bunch of guys put together to make you stuff.. we try to help you make it instead.. this project was put together to help the d3 gain more self sufficient animators.. so.. we aren't gonna be making you pre-rigged arms and hands anytime soon.. sorry

No flexors will not export to d3.. assuming flexors are somewhat similar to 3dsmax's bulge tool (used to make muscles bulge and such.. doesnt apply weight information).. D3 looks only at weights for vertices.. for the bones though, it looks at all normal transformations (move scale rotate)..

If you are getting distorted polys like that, check your weights.. Some vertices may be applied to the wrong bone.. or not blended between bones properly.. Or it might simply be the way your mesh is set up..

Sshots are very useful with questions like these.. (linked please)

post.date: Posted: Tue Feb 15, 2005 6:34 am Post subject:
post.author: Johnny B. Goode
post.body:
Just went through several problems dealing with getting a new weapon to work in this thread:
http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=8759, most of which pertained to the .def file for the weapon.

As far as exporting the animations it depends on what you used to animate them. If you used maya, the exporter is built into doom3. The exports are usually done in the .def file for whatever you're creating, but this does not have to be so. It is explained here:http://www.iddevnet.com/doom3/modelexport.php There is also a MD5 exporter script for maya here:http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=2517, this will allow you to export everything to final format without using Doom3.

If you used a program other than maya, have no fear. You can either bring the models into maya to do the animations, or use one of several available export scripts for your prefered modeling package.

der_ton has created import and export scripts for blender, they can be found here:
Export script>>http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=1711
Import script>>http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=6901

For lightwave:
http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=4595

There's quite a bit of info dealing with importing/exporting for max/gmax in the MAX forum:http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewforum.php?f=53

I'm working with blender, and I'm a noob, so I can't really tell you much about the other programs. I can, however, tell you that those pesky .def and .script files are dealt with in detail in the scripting forum. If you're having a specific problem just post it and I'm sure everybody will do their best to help you out.

Hope that helps,

Johnny

post.date: Posted: Thu Feb 17, 2005 10:05 pm Post subject:
post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
People should really check out Motionbuilder, now owned by alias. I'm currently involved in some motion capture work, which necessitated learning motion builder, as that's what I'm expected to clean the data with.

Anyway, i was blown away by how much of the busywork it takes out of the game. You can set it up so the keys match your preferred 3d program, and it exports between different programs like a champ.

The bipedal premade rigs are a dream. As long as you name your bones like they want, it does all the rigging for you. You still have to skin and paint weights manually, but it takes a lot of the constraints work out of it.

post.date: Posted: Tue May 10, 2005 4:41 pm Post subject: ATT
post.author: JRoot
post.body:
I only just skimmed this thread, but I saw a few things I thought I could chime in on.

Origin Bone
The origin bone is imprtant... so much so that if it doesnt exist in your animation the exporter creates it. It defines the location of the character in the game... So the collision box is relitive to the origin.

If I were a mod crew without an animator, I would build my models and characters right over top of the DOOM3 models (probably using the md5importer) this way our team could take advantage of all the awesome work that Fred and the guys did for you. If the mod takes off ... you could always go back and add new animations or characters with you newfound millions in funding from some major publisher =)

In general the questions seem a bit vauge which makes answering them hard.

~JRoot
Lead Animator id Software
www.johnroot.com

Ok, personally I see animating/exporting weaponsmodels and character/enemy models as two seperate things. (not all might agree)

I would start with the weapons, because they are generally speaking a little bit easier to understand, have less animations (usually only between 5 and 10 different anims) and will teach you the basics for animating for Doom3. The animations itself are quite selfexplanetory. You create bones, attach the bones to the model and animate those bones using keyframes or frame to frame animation. Then, if you position one bone in a certain way part of the model will move accordingly, etc..etc..

What kind of stuff/plugins you'll be using for this depends on which 3d program you use. So, before we can help we'll need to know is which 3d program you're using. Don't expect us to do any animating for you (unless you can find someone crazy enough to do it for you. )

The main goal is to teach you how to do it yourself, so you can help others out in the future.

post.date: Posted: Sun May 22, 2005 8:58 pm Post subject:
post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Oneofthe8devilz wrote:
Is there a way to attach a sound sapeaker to a md5's origin bone ?


You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:

model model_myf16 {
   mesh   models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

   anim fly   models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
                frame 1   sound_body snd_fly
   }


snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.
_________________

Ultimate Mod

Personal websites:
http://www.fabianband.com
http://pixels.ontheweb.nl

post.date: Posted: Sun May 22, 2005 9:22 pm Post subject:
post.author: Oneofthe8devilz
post.body:
Quote:
You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:

model model_myf16 {
mesh models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

anim fly models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
frame 1 sound_body snd_fly
}



snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.



Actually I got it working by looking closer at the "cinematics.def" file a couple of hours ago..... I was just so amazed by the fact that I got it working that I forgot to post you guys ........

Still thanks for that quick response bloodrayne ......

That's how I solved the problem:


Code:
model f16_jet {
   mesh      models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5mesh   
   anim f16flyby   models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5anim {
   frame 1      sound f16_jet_engine
   }
}

entityDef f16_jet {      
      "inherit"   "func_animate"
      "model"      "f16_jet"
}


"f16_jet_engine" is a looped soundshader that starts to play at frame 1 and gets played by the origin bone by default.... you can also define in the entity which bone shall play the sound.........

So once started it plays it infinitive times back......

I hope this might wind up useful for other ppl aswell......

post.date: Posted: Fri Jun 10, 2005 10:06 am Post subject:
post.author: obihb
post.body:
You can animate your weapon in whatever program you can end up getting it into Doom3. I know of Maya and Max being able to do this. If Lightwave can do it then animate in that. The main thing to know is that anything you want to have animation on needs to be animated with bones. Nothing can be animated inside Doom3 with the old Quake3 method of blend verts.

So if you wanted to have the crossbow shoot an arrow, the string needs to be animated with bones, so does the arrow and the hand pulling the trigger and whatever else.

Within Max, the way der_ton's exporter work everything has to be a single mesh. You can't have the arrow a seperate mesh and soforth. Then it just has to be skinned and weighted on the bones you provide to animate each part. The exporter also allow you to use whatever tool is to your disposal like IK or constraints or directly animating it. All this is also possible from within Maya accept for the export to be a longer process and I don't think you have to have a single mesh. I'm sorry I have no experience with Lightwave.

post.date: Posted: Fri Jun 10, 2005 4:49 pm Post subject:
post.author: bad marine ass
post.body:
Brian mentioned this in his reply to my query

Quote:
For the first question, it doesn't really matter a whole lot which
method you use to animate as long as the exported file contains only
bones.


Which means that the only way, the one and only way to animate, is through bones?

post.date: Posted: Fri Jun 10, 2005 6:44 pm Post subject:
post.author: obihb
post.body:
Yes. It has to be bones.

Some confusion might come into some of the posts from Brian in some threads where he talks about der_ton's exporter being able to generate bones for you based on vertex movement. As far as I know it was an experimental exporter made by der_ton to make it possible for easier facial animation. It's not very "game" friendly though because it generates a bone per vertex which ends up being way too much.

The bottom line is that bones is the one and only method to animate in Doom3. Of course the scripted animation is possible on "solid" objects with simple translation and rotation that can be done, no "vertex level" animation like for characters.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

post.author: Zergxes
post.body:
I have a few random questions about D3/Q4 rigs.

1.) what is the optimal number (or maybe just a good target number) of bones to keep things efficent for NPC monsters and for multiplayer characters?

2.) There are some 'floating' bones on some of the Q4 monster rigs that seem to translate around, particularly on the chest of the beserker. How are those set up?

3.) The rigs in Q4 use an inverted foot rig, should I stick to that or can I do the heel-less rig to save bones?

-Right now I'm just slamming out art for my portfolio but I would like to not back myself into a corner should I get the opportunity to get these in game.

Thanks in advance.

post.author: Emperors Teeth
post.body:
Interesting the Doom community should be lacking animators. I have done a lot of work on Dawn on War (until recently), and that community suffered from a chronic lack of texturers... (good) modellers were a rare resource also.

Anyway, I'm interested in getting back into the modding scene, and I'd like to make something look good for my showreel. Doom looks like it might be an excellent way to do so...

post.author: zenarion
post.body:
Dawn of War has a modding community?
Good lord...
Well animators are a rare species in all mod work and fan communities.
It is a pretty hard step to go from 2d drawing to 3d modeling for many. And from that, to 4d animating is even harder. There arent too many tutorials on the internet from which one can learn the basics of animating, which is bad.

If you have done professional work animating, it could be good to have a tutorial presenting how ones makes simple walk cycles and whatnot.

post.author: bhenderson
post.body:
nihil sub sole novum.

Regarding the lack of tutorials:

Look at what other people have done as far as animating walk cycles and the like goes. In example, you could import the .md5anim of the walk cycle for Doom3, and check it out.

Also, 2d animation is very similar to 3d animation, so check out some 2d animation tutorials as well -- you might be surprised.

I have to speed animate all the time, so I don't have the best advice, but this is what has gotten me through a lot of the rough spots.

post.author: zenarion
post.body:
I was referring more to the uses of IK chains and such tools.
I discovered that helpful thing in some of Trepanings tutorials, and it was really helpful.

post.author: DarkViper
post.body:
Hey All,

experienced animator here looking for a little bit of insight.

im wanting to make a Machinima project using pre-existing Doom 3 characters, compatible inside of Doom3.

Im very concerned about the face, as im NOT interested in reworking the entire head structure/rig to make the bloody mouth move properly. However, if its easy preliminary stuff, ones that arent total buzz kills, then im totally up for it.

im not a newb to Id Tech 4 either, I've made simple mods before, just never a custom animated sequence in it. So any help, would be just dandy.

Thanks!

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

post.author: fault_line
post.body:
Ahh.. i see well i guess whatever works the least painfully for you. Im not sure which 3D package you use, but it may possible you can setup key bone poses and copy paste within the software.

Something like this for lightwave : http://www.thomas4d.com/html/t4d_rigging_tools.html (halfway down page - Negative Frame paste plugins)
The bone phoneme positions in the face are created in negative frames then using the plugin they're essentially pasted into the frame you choose.
But again, whatever gets the job done with minimal hair pulling

faultline
http://eammon.endysis.org

post.author: kat
post.body:
fault_line wrote:
but it may possible you can setup key bone poses and copy paste within the software.
That's actually what you'll need to do in order to you save on time, resources and file sizes. There are probably 'Pro' ways to do it (but not everyone has access to a motion capture rig..!) but so long as you you have a pose for the phonetic sounds and a couple of other general 'features' you should be able to 'morph' them together inside your 3D app as it naturally blends each pose with the next.

post.author: crimity
post.body:
Like Bloodrayne said.. the animators think tank is not a bunch of guys put together to make you stuff.. we try to help you make it instead.. this project was put together to help the d3 gain more self sufficient animators.. so.. we aren't gonna be making you pre-rigged arms and hands anytime soon.. sorry

No flexors will not export to d3.. assuming flexors are somewhat similar to 3dsmax's bulge tool (used to make muscles bulge and such.. doesnt apply weight information).. D3 looks only at weights for vertices.. for the bones though, it looks at all normal transformations (move scale rotate)..

If you are getting distorted polys like that, check your weights.. Some vertices may be applied to the wrong bone.. or not blended between bones properly.. Or it might simply be the way your mesh is set up..

Sshots are very useful with questions like these.. (linked please)

post.author: Johnny B. Goode
post.body:
Just went through several problems dealing with getting a new weapon to work in this thread:
http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=8759, most of which pertained to the .def file for the weapon.

As far as exporting the animations it depends on what you used to animate them. If you used maya, the exporter is built into doom3. The exports are usually done in the .def file for whatever you're creating, but this does not have to be so. It is explained here:http://www.iddevnet.com/doom3/modelexport.php There is also a MD5 exporter script for maya here:http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=2517, this will allow you to export everything to final format without using Doom3.

If you used a program other than maya, have no fear. You can either bring the models into maya to do the animations, or use one of several available export scripts for your prefered modeling package.

der_ton has created import and export scripts for blender, they can be found here:
Export script>>http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=1711
Import script>>http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=6901

For lightwave:
http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=4595

There's quite a bit of info dealing with importing/exporting for max/gmax in the MAX forum:http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewforum.php?f=53

I'm working with blender, and I'm a noob, so I can't really tell you much about the other programs. I can, however, tell you that those pesky .def and .script files are dealt with in detail in the scripting forum. If you're having a specific problem just post it and I'm sure everybody will do their best to help you out.

Hope that helps,

Johnny

If that does not happen, then this little known program will serve no one any good for Doom 3, so I won't even mention its name.

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
People should really check out Motionbuilder, now owned by alias. I'm currently involved in some motion capture work, which necessitated learning motion builder, as that's what I'm expected to clean the data with.

Anyway, i was blown away by how much of the busywork it takes out of the game. You can set it up so the keys match your preferred 3d program, and it exports between different programs like a champ.

The bipedal premade rigs are a dream. As long as you name your bones like they want, it does all the rigging for you. You still have to skin and paint weights manually, but it takes a lot of the constraints work out of it.

post.author: JRoot
post.body:
I only just skimmed this thread, but I saw a few things I thought I could chime in on.

Origin Bone
The origin bone is imprtant... so much so that if it doesnt exist in your animation the exporter creates it. It defines the location of the character in the game... So the collision box is relitive to the origin.

If I were a mod crew without an animator, I would build my models and characters right over top of the DOOM3 models (probably using the md5importer) this way our team could take advantage of all the awesome work that Fred and the guys did for you. If the mod takes off ... you could always go back and add new animations or characters with you newfound millions in funding from some major publisher =)

In general the questions seem a bit vauge which makes answering them hard.

~JRoot
Lead Animator id Software
http://www.johnroot.com

post.author: crimity
post.body:
Wow.. Didn't know you were going to be animating for Id.. That's awesome..

Thanks for adding that bit of info.. on a side note for others reading.. the entity itself can also follow the origin bone I believe.. So the animator can actually have it move around their modelling program without having to reposition the entire bone structure on export.. This is extremely nice when having a npc interact with the environment.. or just for walking animations even..

I've finally gotten a chance to really start looking a little more in depth at d3's animation.. So I'll probably do more chiming myself soon..

post.body:
compuguy76 wrote:

-compguru76@yahoo.com


Ok, personally I see animating/exporting weaponsmodels and character/enemy models as two seperate things. (not all might agree)

I would start with the weapons, because they are generally speaking a little bit easier to understand, have less animations (usually only between 5 and 10 different anims) and will teach you the basics for animating for Doom3. The animations itself are quite selfexplanetory. You create bones, attach the bones to the model and animate those bones using keyframes or frame to frame animation. Then, if you position one bone in a certain way part of the model will move accordingly, etc..etc..

What kind of stuff/plugins you'll be using for this depends on which 3d program you use. So, before we can help we'll need to know is which 3d program you're using. Don't expect us to do any animating for you (unless you can find someone crazy enough to do it for you. )

The main goal is to teach you how to do it yourself, so you can help others out in the future.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Oneofthe8devilz wrote:
Is there a way to attach a sound sapeaker to a md5's origin bone ?


You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:
model model_myf16 {
   mesh   models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

   anim fly   models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
                frame 1   sound_body snd_fly
   }


snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.

post.author: Oneofthe8devilz
post.body:
Quote:
You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:

model model_myf16 {
mesh models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

anim fly models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
frame 1 sound_body snd_fly
}



snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.



Actually I got it working by looking closer at the "cinematics.def" file a couple of hours ago..... I was just so amazed by the fact that I got it working that I forgot to post you guys ........

Still thanks for that quick response bloodrayne ......

That's how I solved the problem:


Code:
model f16_jet {
   mesh      models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5mesh   
   anim f16flyby   models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5anim {
   frame 1      sound f16_jet_engine
   }
}

entityDef f16_jet {      
      "inherit"   "func_animate"
      "model"      "f16_jet"
}


"f16_jet_engine" is a looped soundshader that starts to play at frame 1 and gets played by the origin bone by default.... you can also define in the entity which bone shall play the sound.........

So once started it plays it infinitive times back......

I hope this might wind up useful for other ppl aswell......

post.author: obihb
post.body:
You can animate your weapon in whatever program you can end up getting it into Doom3. I know of Maya and Max being able to do this. If Lightwave can do it then animate in that. The main thing to know is that anything you want to have animation on needs to be animated with bones. Nothing can be animated inside Doom3 with the old Quake3 method of blend verts.

So if you wanted to have the crossbow shoot an arrow, the string needs to be animated with bones, so does the arrow and the hand pulling the trigger and whatever else.

Within Max, the way der_ton's exporter work everything has to be a single mesh. You can't have the arrow a seperate mesh and soforth. Then it just has to be skinned and weighted on the bones you provide to animate each part. The exporter also allow you to use whatever tool is to your disposal like IK or constraints or directly animating it. All this is also possible from within Maya accept for the export to be a longer process and I don't think you have to have a single mesh. I'm sorry I have no experience with Lightwave.

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body:
Brian mentioned this in his reply to my query

Quote:
For the first question, it doesn't really matter a whole lot which
method you use to animate as long as the exported file contains only
bones.


Which means that the only way, the one and only way to animate, is through bones?

post.author: obihb
post.body:
Yes. It has to be bones.

Some confusion might come into some of the posts from Brian in some threads where he talks about der_ton's exporter being able to generate bones for you based on vertex movement. As far as I know it was an experimental exporter made by der_ton to make it possible for easier facial animation. It's not very "game" friendly though because it generates a bone per vertex which ends up being way too much.

The bottom line is that bones is the one and only method to animate in Doom3. Of course the scripted animation is possible on "solid" objects with simple translation and rotation that can be done, no "vertex level" animation like for characters.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

_________________
Hexen: Edge of Chaos Total Conversion for Doom 3.

post.author: Oneofthe8devilz
post.body:
Is there a way to attach a sound sapeaker to a md5's origin bone ?

I have a scene where a f-16 jet is flying through the level (animated in 3dsmax and exported to md5) and I would like to add some jet engine sounds to it that move with the jet....... just binding the speaker to the model-entity's name didn't do the trick since the entity itself is not moving .........

Thanks for some suggestions in advance

post.author: SnoopJeDi
post.body:
I'm a dummy with models, but you could probably create an invisible func_mover, bind the speaker to that, and move it to sync up with the anim.

There's probably a way to bind the speaker though, since there is a way to bind the flashlight to a zombie's hand.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Oneofthe8devilz wrote:
Is there a way to attach a sound sapeaker to a md5's origin bone ?


You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:
model model_myf16 {
   mesh   models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

   anim fly   models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
                frame 1   sound_body snd_fly
   }


snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.

post.author: Oneofthe8devilz
post.body:
Quote:
You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:

model model_myf16 {
mesh models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

anim fly models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
frame 1 sound_body snd_fly
}



snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.



Actually I got it working by looking closer at the "cinematics.def" file a couple of hours ago..... I was just so amazed by the fact that I got it working that I forgot to post you guys ........

Still thanks for that quick response bloodrayne ......

That's how I solved the problem:


Code:
model f16_jet {
   mesh      models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5mesh   
   anim f16flyby   models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5anim {
   frame 1      sound f16_jet_engine
   }
}

entityDef f16_jet {      
      "inherit"   "func_animate"
      "model"      "f16_jet"
}


"f16_jet_engine" is a looped soundshader that starts to play at frame 1 and gets played by the origin bone by default.... you can also define in the entity which bone shall play the sound.........

So once started it plays it infinitive times back......

I hope this might wind up useful for other ppl aswell......

post.author: rich_is_bored

Well if you have any intention of exporting that weapon to Doom 3 then you'd best forget all the special animation tools Lightwave affords you and stick to using bones because bone transformations are the only transformations that can be stored in a MD5anim.

Aside from that you'll probably need to merge all the layers aswell.

post.author: obihb
post.body:
You can animate your weapon in whatever program you can end up getting it into Doom3. I know of Maya and Max being able to do this. If Lightwave can do it then animate in that. The main thing to know is that anything you want to have animation on needs to be animated with bones. Nothing can be animated inside Doom3 with the old Quake3 method of blend verts.

So if you wanted to have the crossbow shoot an arrow, the string needs to be animated with bones, so does the arrow and the hand pulling the trigger and whatever else.

Within Max, the way der_ton's exporter work everything has to be a single mesh. You can't have the arrow a seperate mesh and soforth. Then it just has to be skinned and weighted on the bones you provide to animate each part. The exporter also allow you to use whatever tool is to your disposal like IK or constraints or directly animating it. All this is also possible from within Maya accept for the export to be a longer process and I don't think you have to have a single mesh. I'm sorry I have no experience with Lightwave.

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body:
Brian mentioned this in his reply to my query

Quote:
For the first question, it doesn't really matter a whole lot which
method you use to animate as long as the exported file contains only
bones.


Which means that the only way, the one and only way to animate, is through bones?

post.author: obihb
post.body:
Yes. It has to be bones.

Some confusion might come into some of the posts from Brian in some threads where he talks about der_ton's exporter being able to generate bones for you based on vertex movement. As far as I know it was an experimental exporter made by der_ton to make it possible for easier facial animation. It's not very "game" friendly though because it generates a bone per vertex which ends up being way too much.

The bottom line is that bones is the one and only method to animate in Doom3. Of course the scripted animation is possible on "solid" objects with simple translation and rotation that can be done, no "vertex level" animation like for characters.

post.author: crimity
post.body:
Like Bloodrayne said.. the animators think tank is not a bunch of guys put together to make you stuff.. we try to help you make it instead.. this project was put together to help the d3 gain more self sufficient animators.. so.. we aren't gonna be making you pre-rigged arms and hands anytime soon.. sorry

No flexors will not export to d3.. assuming flexors are somewhat similar to 3dsmax's bulge tool (used to make muscles bulge and such.. doesnt apply weight information).. D3 looks only at weights for vertices.. for the bones though, it looks at all normal transformations (move scale rotate)..

If you are getting distorted polys like that, check your weights.. Some vertices may be applied to the wrong bone.. or not blended between bones properly.. Or it might simply be the way your mesh is set up..

Sshots are very useful with questions like these.. (linked please)

post.author: Johnny B. Goode
post.body:
Just went through several problems dealing with getting a new weapon to work in this thread:
http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=8759, most of which pertained to the .def file for the weapon.

As far as exporting the animations it depends on what you used to animate them. If you used maya, the exporter is built into doom3. The exports are usually done in the .def file for whatever you're creating, but this does not have to be so. It is explained here:http://www.iddevnet.com/doom3/modelexport.php There is also a MD5 exporter script for maya here:http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=2517, this will allow you to export everything to final format without using Doom3.

If you used a program other than maya, have no fear. You can either bring the models into maya to do the animations, or use one of several available export scripts for your prefered modeling package.

der_ton has created import and export scripts for blender, they can be found here:
Export script>>http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=1711
Import script>>http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=6901

For lightwave:
http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewtopic.php?t=4595

There's quite a bit of info dealing with importing/exporting for max/gmax in the MAX forum:http://www.doom3world.org/phpbb2/viewforum.php?f=53

I'm working with blender, and I'm a noob, so I can't really tell you much about the other programs. I can, however, tell you that those pesky .def and .script files are dealt with in detail in the scripting forum. If you're having a specific problem just post it and I'm sure everybody will do their best to help you out.

Hope that helps,

Johnny

post.author: parsonsbear
post.body:
People should really check out Motionbuilder, now owned by alias. I'm currently involved in some motion capture work, which necessitated learning motion builder, as that's what I'm expected to clean the data with.

Anyway, i was blown away by how much of the busywork it takes out of the game. You can set it up so the keys match your preferred 3d program, and it exports between different programs like a champ.

The bipedal premade rigs are a dream. As long as you name your bones like they want, it does all the rigging for you. You still have to skin and paint weights manually, but it takes a lot of the constraints work out of it.

post.author: JRoot
post.body:
I only just skimmed this thread, but I saw a few things I thought I could chime in on.

Origin Bone
The origin bone is imprtant... so much so that if it doesnt exist in your animation the exporter creates it. It defines the location of the character in the game... So the collision box is relitive to the origin.

If I were a mod crew without an animator, I would build my models and characters right over top of the DOOM3 models (probably using the md5importer) this way our team could take advantage of all the awesome work that Fred and the guys did for you. If the mod takes off ... you could always go back and add new animations or characters with you newfound millions in funding from some major publisher =)

In general the questions seem a bit vauge which makes answering them hard.

~JRoot
Lead Animator id Software
http://www.johnroot.com

post.author: crimity
post.body:
Wow.. Didn't know you were going to be animating for Id.. That's awesome..

Thanks for adding that bit of info.. on a side note for others reading.. the entity itself can also follow the origin bone I believe.. So the animator can actually have it move around their modelling program without having to reposition the entire bone structure on export.. This is extremely nice when having a npc interact with the environment.. or just for walking animations even..

I've finally gotten a chance to really start looking a little more in depth at d3's animation.. So I'll probably do more chiming myself soon..

Ok, personally I see animating/exporting weaponsmodels and character/enemy models as two seperate things. (not all might agree)

I would start with the weapons, because they are generally speaking a little bit easier to understand, have less animations (usually only between 5 and 10 different anims) and will teach you the basics for animating for Doom3. The animations itself are quite selfexplanetory. You create bones, attach the bones to the model and animate those bones using keyframes or frame to frame animation. Then, if you position one bone in a certain way part of the model will move accordingly, etc..etc..

What kind of stuff/plugins you'll be using for this depends on which 3d program you use. So, before we can help we'll need to know is which 3d program you're using. Don't expect us to do any animating for you (unless you can find someone crazy enough to do it for you. )

The main goal is to teach you how to do it yourself, so you can help others out in the future.

post.author: SnoopJeDi
post.body:

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Oneofthe8devilz wrote:
Is there a way to attach a sound sapeaker to a md5's origin bone ?


You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:
model model_myf16 {
   mesh   models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

   anim fly   models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
                frame 1   sound_body snd_fly
   }


snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.

post.author: Oneofthe8devilz
post.body:
Quote:
You don't need to, since it's an entity you can just call the sound from the animation def. An example:

Code:

model model_myf16 {
mesh models/md5/my_f16.md5mesh

anim fly models/md5/my_f16_fly.md5anim {
frame 1 sound_body snd_fly
}



snd_fly is then just a sounddecls you can define anywhere as soundshader.



Actually I got it working by looking closer at the "cinematics.def" file a couple of hours ago..... I was just so amazed by the fact that I got it working that I forgot to post you guys ........

Still thanks for that quick response bloodrayne ......

That's how I solved the problem:


Code:
model f16_jet {
   mesh      models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5mesh   
   anim f16flyby   models/chris_md5/f16_jet.md5anim {
   frame 1      sound f16_jet_engine
   }
}

entityDef f16_jet {      
      "inherit"   "func_animate"
      "model"      "f16_jet"
}


"f16_jet_engine" is a looped soundshader that starts to play at frame 1 and gets played by the origin bone by default.... you can also define in the entity which bone shall play the sound.........

So once started it plays it infinitive times back......

I hope this might wind up useful for other ppl aswell......

post.author: obihb
post.body:
You can animate your weapon in whatever program you can end up getting it into Doom3. I know of Maya and Max being able to do this. If Lightwave can do it then animate in that. The main thing to know is that anything you want to have animation on needs to be animated with bones. Nothing can be animated inside Doom3 with the old Quake3 method of blend verts.

So if you wanted to have the crossbow shoot an arrow, the string needs to be animated with bones, so does the arrow and the hand pulling the trigger and whatever else.

Within Max, the way der_ton's exporter work everything has to be a single mesh. You can't have the arrow a seperate mesh and soforth. Then it just has to be skinned and weighted on the bones you provide to animate each part. The exporter also allow you to use whatever tool is to your disposal like IK or constraints or directly animating it. All this is also possible from within Maya accept for the export to be a longer process and I don't think you have to have a single mesh. I'm sorry I have no experience with Lightwave.

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body:
Brian mentioned this in his reply to my query

Quote:
For the first question, it doesn't really matter a whole lot which
method you use to animate as long as the exported file contains only
bones.


Which means that the only way, the one and only way to animate, is through bones?

post.author: obihb
post.body:
Yes. It has to be bones.

Some confusion might come into some of the posts from Brian in some threads where he talks about der_ton's exporter being able to generate bones for you based on vertex movement. As far as I know it was an experimental exporter made by der_ton to make it possible for easier facial animation. It's not very "game" friendly though because it generates a bone per vertex which ends up being way too much.

The bottom line is that bones is the one and only method to animate in Doom3. Of course the scripted animation is possible on "solid" objects with simple translation and rotation that can be done, no "vertex level" animation like for characters.

I have 2 questions:

1) my crossbow is made up of 7-8 different layers of parts ie. trigger in one layer, handle in one layer etc, do I need to combine them?
2) How do I actually get the crossbow to behave in the above-mentioned way? Any help will be appreciated. I've been reading the tutorials, and I've heard of the motion mixer plugin and stuff like that, but I'm very confused as to how I should get myself orientated and started with this

post.author: rich_is_bored
post.body:
Well if you have any intention of exporting that weapon to Doom 3 then you'd best forget all the special animation tools Lightwave affords you and stick to using bones because bone transformations are the only transformations that can be stored in a MD5anim.

Aside from that you'll probably need to merge all the layers aswell.

post.author: Brain Trepaning
post.body: You don't need to animate with bones to use der_ton's general MD5 exporter, but that's for 3ds Max.

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body: I'll be using bones for the rope, but the other movements like the bolt (that little thingy holding the rope taut) and the recoil movement of the crossbow itself, do I have to use bones too?

post.author: der_ton
post.body: I think it's best if you try out the process of getting an animated model from LW into D3 with an example, instead of putting lots of time into animating your model with the wrong methods, walking down a long road just to see it's a dead end.

post.author: Fingernail
post.body:
Although we need animators (Dark Mod), we're probably not the MOST at need. We have a couple of people at least capable of animating, and we've got about three animations in on a couple of characters (walking, running, punching), but it's great to see the community recognising this "problem".

Depending on how things go, we may need your help, but with us it's a case of, we have a couple of people who CAN do animations, it's just that they also have a helluva lot of models to do and don't have the time to ONLY do animations, etc. etc. We're just about to go on a bit of an "advertising campaign" searching for animators, actually.

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body: Hmm it seems that the animations don't work the way I thought they should work. I thought it was something like Flash, whereby the polygons moved frame by frame. How exactly do the bones work? I'm halfway thru an animation tutorial, but I still don't quite get it

post.author: doomkid3000
post.body: you want to setup your bone skeleton with IK's in whatever program your using, so that when you animate your charactor its easy to manipulate the movements, without having to animate each bone making life alot easier

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body: So basically the weapons would work exactly like the characters do?

post.author: doomkid3000
post.body: i dont think so, unless you have some crazy weapon design that has a crazy type of animation, then YES

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body: which means that maya is the only way to animate weapons?

post.author: obihb
post.body:
You can animate your weapon in whatever program you can end up getting it into Doom3. I know of Maya and Max being able to do this. If Lightwave can do it then animate in that. The main thing to know is that anything you want to have animation on needs to be animated with bones. Nothing can be animated inside Doom3 with the old Quake3 method of blend verts.

So if you wanted to have the crossbow shoot an arrow, the string needs to be animated with bones, so does the arrow and the hand pulling the trigger and whatever else.

Within Max, the way der_ton's exporter work everything has to be a single mesh. You can't have the arrow a seperate mesh and soforth. Then it just has to be skinned and weighted on the bones you provide to animate each part. The exporter also allow you to use whatever tool is to your disposal like IK or constraints or directly animating it. All this is also possible from within Maya accept for the export to be a longer process and I don't think you have to have a single mesh. I'm sorry I have no experience with Lightwave.

post.author: bad marine ass
post.body:
Brian mentioned this in his reply to my query

Quote:
For the first question, it doesn't really matter a whole lot which
method you use to animate as long as the exported file contains only
bones.


Which means that the only way, the one and only way to animate, is through bones?

post.author: obihb
post.body:
Yes. It has to be bones.

Some confusion might come into some of the posts from Brian in some threads where he talks about der_ton's exporter being able to generate bones for you based on vertex movement. As far as I know it was an experimental exporter made by der_ton to make it possible for easier facial animation. It's not very "game" friendly though because it generates a bone per vertex which ends up being way too much.

The bottom line is that bones is the one and only method to animate in Doom3. Of course the scripted animation is possible on "solid" objects with simple translation and rotation that can be done, no "vertex level" animation like for characters.

I have a few random questions about D3/Q4 rigs.

post.author: Emperors Teeth
post.body:
Interesting the Doom community should be lacking animators. I have done a lot of work on Dawn on War (until recently), and that community suffered from a chronic lack of texturers... (good) modellers were a rare resource also.

Anyway, I'm interested in getting back into the modding scene, and I'd like to make something look good for my showreel. Doom looks like it might be an excellent way to do so...

post.author: zenarion
post.body:
Dawn of War has a modding community?
Good lord...
Well animators are a rare species in all mod work and fan communities.
It is a pretty hard step to go from 2d drawing to 3d modeling for many. And from that, to 4d animating is even harder. There arent too many tutorials on the internet from which one can learn the basics of animating, which is bad.

If you have done professional work animating, it could be good to have a tutorial presenting how ones makes simple walk cycles and whatnot.

post.author: bhenderson
post.body:
nihil sub sole novum.

Regarding the lack of tutorials:

Look at what other people have done as far as animating walk cycles and the like goes. In example, you could import the .md5anim of the walk cycle for Doom3, and check it out.

Also, 2d animation is very similar to 3d animation, so check out some 2d animation tutorials as well -- you might be surprised.

I have to speed animate all the time, so I don't have the best advice, but this is what has gotten me through a lot of the rough spots.

post.author: zenarion
post.body:
I was referring more to the uses of IK chains and such tools.
I discovered that helpful thing in some of Trepanings tutorials, and it was really helpful.

post.author: DarkViper
post.body:

experienced animator here looking for a little bit of insight.

im wanting to make a Machinima project using pre-existing Doom 3 characters, compatible inside of Doom3.
(basically: think of an average cutscene). But because ID doesn't provide the character models, whats the best way to go about this?

Im very concerned about the face, as im NOT interested in reworking the entire head structure/rig to make the bloody mouth move properly. However, if its easy preliminary stuff, ones that arent total buzz kills, then im totally up for it.

im not a newb to Id Tech 4 either, I've made simple mods before, just never a custom animated sequence in it. So any help, would be just dandy.

Thanks!

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

 Post subject: Animators Think Tank.

Captured the Flag

Joined: Fri Aug 13, 2004 3:39 pm
Posts: 1777
Location: Beyond the Veil
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

_________________
Hexen: Edge of Chaos Total Conversion for Doom 3.

Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

Maybe the best way to get the best "bang-for-buck" is to make it a condition that mod makers can only ask the ATT for a tutorial to be written for an specific area (but not for a specific mod or specific model). That way general information any mod maker can use is produced.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

post.author: Dingo_aus
post.body:
BloodRayne wrote:

1 - The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.

2 - Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.


Maybe the best way to get the best "bang-for-buck" is to make it a condition that mod makers can only ask the ATT for a tutorial to be written for an specific area (but not for a specific mod or specific model). That way general information any mod maker can use is produced.

  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

post.author: Dingo_aus
post.body:
BloodRayne wrote:

1 - The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.

2 - Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.


Maybe the best way to get the best "bang-for-buck" is to make it a condition that mod makers can only ask the ATT for a tutorial to be written for an specific area (but not for a specific mod or specific model). That way general information any mod maker can use is produced.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.

post.author: BloodRayne
post.body:
Welcome to the Animators Think Tank!
With some mods being forced to stop in part due to a lack of animators and with the extreme shortage of real animators in the Doom3 community We have started a think tank of animators offering their help to established mod teams in need of animation help.

The team members are:
  • BloodRayne - Weapons Animation Advice
  • crimity
  • der_ton - Technical Advisor
Tentative Members:
  • Johnny B. Goode
  • fault_line
On a side note: We need more animators and I know they're out there. This idea (and some mods as well) will stand or fall with finding animators capable of spending time on this. I myself am really *really* busy but I feel it's important to contribute to this so I will step up myself as the first member, but not as teamleader. I have knowledge and some experience in animating weapons and I would like to share whatever I know with the modding community.

So, if you can animate for Doom3 or if you are an animator for a modteam currently working on a mod then I would like to ask you to join the Animators Think Tank that will help out the entire modding community and hopefully prevent more mods from having to stop due to the lack of Animators currently available for Doom3.

Mod teams can ask the Animators Think Tank (or ATT in short) for help, with only a few conditions in return:
  • The mod team has read and tried the several tutorials available to them. (will be made available in this thread/post).
  • The mod team tries to learn as much as possible from this help in order to learn the animation part as soon as possible so they can carry on the work for the mod themselves.
  • Help can consist of making example animations and scenes for the current 3d packages available. The Animators Think Tank is *not* a quick way to have some people animate stuff for your mod, it should be a great step forward into learning animation and should offer you real tangeable help in the form of example scenes with the models of the mod in question.
  • The mod team asking for help is working for an established mod, has a working, finished, model that needs to be animated and have a website with screenshots to prove it.
  • If a future animator succesfully learns from the mod team then he/she offers his/her services to the Think Tank so we can help others out as well.
